forecast: The Minnesota Timberwolves are favored to win against the Dallas Mavericks based on their early defensive strengths and outstanding performances from Anthony Edwards and Julius Randle.
resolution_criteria: This question resolves as the winning team being either the Minnesota Timberwolves or the Dallas Mavericks based on which team scores more points at the end of their game on October 29, 2024.
reasoning: The Timberwolves have shown they can capitalize on roster depth and strong starts from star players. Their strategic roster moves indicate a focus on winning. Meanwhile, the Mavericks face challenges in consistency, and though Doncic's exploits are legendary, support may be lacking. Minnesota's home court advantage and form over the past games additionally supports the forecast.

sources.eng_title: Minnesota Timberwolves Make Roster Move Before Mavs Game
sources.summary: The Minnesota Timberwolves announced several roster moves before their game against the Dallas Mavericks, assigning forward Leonard Miller to the G League affiliate Iowa Wolves. Miller, the 33rd pick in the 2023 NBA Draft, averaged 1.7 points and 1.2 rebounds per game in his rookie year. The team also transferred guard Jaylen Clark and center Jesse Edwards to the Iowa Wolves. The Timberwolves enter the game with a 2-1 record, led by All-Star forward Julius Randle, who scored 24 points and grabbed nine rebounds in their last game against the Toronto Raptors.
sources.title: Minnesota Timberwolves Make Roster Move Before Mavs Game

sources.eng_title: Every NBA Team's Most Fun Player To Watch During This Season
sources.summary: The 2024-25 NBA season has tipped off with exciting performances from various players across the league. Trae Young of the Atlanta Hawks is known for his electric shooting range and fearless drives, making him a thrill to watch. Jayson Tatum of the Boston Celtics has shown versatility and scoring ability, leading the team to a strong start. Cam Thomas of the Brooklyn Nets has become the team's primary offensive weapon, scoring from all three levels and hitting tough shots. LaMelo Ball of the Charlotte Hornets has made waves with his flashy passes, deep threes, and high IQ on the court. Zach LaVine of the Chicago Bulls has opened the season in strong form, proving why he's the team's most electrifying player. Donovan Mitchell of the Cleveland Cavaliers has started the season on fire, reminding everyone why he's the team's main guy. Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks has delivered jaw-dropping performances, showcasing his relentless scoring ability. Nikola Jokic of the Denver Nuggets has been putting up big numbers, but the team's opening hasn't gone as planned. Cade Cunningham of the Detroit Pistons has started the season strong, showing why he's the team's cornerstone. Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors has hit the ground running, delivering stellar performances in the team's first two games. Jalen Green of the Houston Rockets has wasted no time bringing excitement to the team's season, showcasing his explosive drives and flashy footwork. Tyrese Haliburton of the Indiana Pacers has started the season with some impressive performances, setting the tone for the team. Kawhi Leonard of the Los Angeles Clippers is currently sidelined due to a knee injury, but his absence leaves a major gap in the team's lineup. LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers has dropped a jaw-dropping triple-double, showing his ability to take over late and push the team to a 3-0 start. Ja Morant of the Memphis Grizzlies has brought his signature energy and showmanship to the team, delivering standout performances. Jimmy Butler of the Miami Heat has come roaring back in the team's next game, dropping 26 points with 8 assists to lead the Heat past Charlotte. Giannis Antetokounmpo of the Milwaukee Bucks has opened the season with a bang, putting up classic 'Greek Freak' performances. Anthony Edwards of the Minnesota Timberwolves has kicked off the season in serious form, showing why he's the face of the franchise. Zion Williamson of the New Orleans Pelicans has had a strong start to the season, showcasing his versatility and impact on both ends of the floor. Jalen Brunson of the New York Knicks has started this season as the team's go-to offensive force, delivering efficient scoring right from the jump.
sources.title: Every NBA Team's Most Fun Player To Watch During This Season

sources.eng_title: Driscoll predicts Grizzlies' Western Conference success
sources.summary: NBA journalist Chris Driscoll predicts that the Memphis Grizzlies will finish second in the Western Conference with a record of 54-28. Driscoll believes that the Grizzlies will surpass the Denver Nuggets, Minnesota Timberwolves, Sacramento Kings, and Phoenix Suns, who will secure the top six playoff spots. He is also optimistic about Ja Morant's return to All-NBA form, citing Desmond Bane and Jaren Jackson Jr.'s ability to complement Morant's play, as well as the addition of Marcus Smart. Driscoll is high on the Grizzlies, but low on the Dallas Mavericks, predicting they will finish seventh with 44 wins.
sources.title: Driscoll predicts Grizzlies' Western Conference success

sources.eng_title: NBA 2024-25 roundup: Kevin Durant hits milestone in Suns win against Mavericks
sources.summary: The NBA 2024-25 season continued with several games on Saturday night. Kevin Durant led the Phoenix Suns to a 114-102 victory over the Dallas Mavericks, becoming the eighth player in NBA history to top 29,000 career points. LeBron James had 32 points, 14 rebounds, and 10 assists to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 131-127 win over the Sacramento Kings. The Oklahoma City Thunder spoiled Lonzo Ball's first game back in Chicago with a 114-95 victory. Other results included the Clippers beating the Nuggets 109-104, the Celtics defeating the Pistons 124-118, the Timberwolves beating the Raptors 112-101, the Cavaliers cruising past the Wizards 135-116, the Heat topping the Hornets 114-106, the Grizzlies beating the Magic 124-111, and the Spurs outlasting the Rockets 109-106.
sources.title: NBA 2024-25 roundup: Kevin Durant hits milestone in Suns win against Mavericks

sources.eng_title: Anthony Edwards Made NBA History In Raptors-Timberwolves Game
sources.summary: Anthony Edwards made NBA history by becoming the youngest player to reach 800 career threes in the league, achieving this feat at 23 years and 82 days old. He tied Stephen Curry for the fifth-fastest player to reach this milestone, requiring only 305 career games. Edwards has established himself as one of the top 15 players in the NBA, averaging 29.5 points, 6.5 rebounds, and 3.5 assists per game through the first two games of the season. The Minnesota Timberwolves are 1-1 in their first two games, with Edwards leading the team in scoring and performance. He finished the previous game with 32 points, seven rebounds, and four assists, and will face the Dallas Mavericks in their next game on Tuesday.
sources.title: Anthony Edwards Made NBA History In Raptors-Timberwolves Game

timeline: Oct 27, 2024: Mavericks lose to Phoenix Suns 114-102.
Oct 28, 2024: Timberwolves announce G League assignments ahead of the game.

Luka Doncic of the Mavericks scored a team-high 28 points in Game 4, but the Mavericks lost 105-100.
Anthony Edwards leads the Timberwolves with an average of 27.5 points per game in the playoffs.

Key injuries include Luka Doncic (questionable) and Mike Conley (questionable) for their respective teams.
Predicted outcome: Timberwolves 107, Mavericks 105, with a recommendation to bet on Mavericks +4.5 and the Over 209.5.

Dallas Mavericks at Minnesota Timberwolves Game 5 odds, picks and predictions
=============================================================================

May 29, 2024 8:58 pm ET

The **Minnesota Timberwolves** welcome the **Dallas Mavericks** to Target Center for Game 5 of the best-of-7 Western Conference Finals Thursday. The Mavericks lead the series 3-1. Tip-off is scheduled for 8:30 p.m. ET (TNT). Let’s analyze  lines around the **Mavericks vs. Timberwolves** **odds** and make our expert .

The Mavericks ripped off 3 straight wins to open this series, covering in each. They did come up short in Game 4, though, losing 105-100 Tuesday after closing as 1.5-point favorites. G **Luka Doncic** ended with a team-high 28 points but hit just 7 of 21 from the field.

Dallas beat the LA Clippers in 6 games in the 1st round and also won its 2nd-round series against the Oklahoma City Thunder in 6, covering 7 of 12 before the conference finals. The Mavs are 6-2 against the spread (ATS) on the road in the playoffs.

G **Anthony Edwards**, who leads the Wolves with 27.5 points per game in the playoffs, had his best performance of the series in Game 4, ending with 29 points and 10 rebounds.

As for Minnesota, the Wolves took down the defending champs, the Denver Nuggets, in 7 games in their 2nd-round series and swept the Phoenix Suns in the 1st round. They are 9-6 ATS through their 15 postseason games and 3-3 ATS as favorites.

Mavericks at Timberwolves odds
------------------------------

Provided by ; access  for a full list. Lines last updated at 8:58 p.m. ET.

*   **Moneyline (ML)**: Mavericks +166 (bet $100 to win $166) | Timberwolves -198 (bet $198 to win $100)
*   **Against the spread**: Mavericks +4.5 (-108) | Timberwolves -4.5 (-114)
*   **Over/Under (O/U)**: 209.5 (O: -110 | U: -110)

Mavericks at Timberwolves key injuries
--------------------------------------

Mavericks

*   G **Luka Doncic** (knee, ankle) questionable
*   C **Dereck Lively II** (neck) questionable

Timberwolves

*   G **Mike Conley** (Achilles) questionable

For most recent updates: .

Play our free daily **** and win! ****!

Mavericks at Timberwolves picks and predictions
-----------------------------------------------

### Prediction

Timberwolves 107, Mavericks 105

### 

**PASS**.

Unless one would rather back the Mavs on the moneyline than the spread, there’s not much value here. The Wolves (-198) are too pricey, and the Mavs have had each of their 1st 2 series end in 6 games.

Expect Minnesota to come out on top here, but avoid taking it at -198.

### 

**LEAN MAVERICKS +4.5** (**\-108**).

In NBA standards, these games have had ultra-close finishes. All 4 games have been single-digit victories, and 3 of the 4 have been won by 5 or fewer points. The Mavericks are 5-1 ATS as underdogs in the postseason, and they are 4-0 ATS through their last 4 games on the road.

Minnesota had a perfect style of play to down Denver and throttled a disoriented Phoenix team. While those were impressive, the Mavs have shown to be a more challenging matchup, and this should continue to be a hard-fought series. Since May 10, the Wolves have been favored 5 times and are 1-4 ATS in those games.

Back **MAVERICKS +4.5** (**\-108**).

### 

**BET OVER 209.5** (**\-110**).

Both teams are trending towards the Over, as is the series as a whole.

The Wolves have gone Over in 6 of their last 9 and are 5-2 O/U in their 7 home playoff games this season. Similarly, the Mavs have gone Over in 8 of their last 13 games and are 4-2 O/U in their last 6 on the road.

Three of 4 games in the series have gone Over, and in the lone one that didn’t, the Mavs shot 42% while G **Kyrie Irving** and Doncic combined to hit just 13 of 39 from the field. The superstars should play better in their 2nd potential close-out game.

Back **OVER 209.5** (**\-110**).

Mavericks vs Timberwolves Prediction, Picks, Odds for Tonight’s NBA Playoff Game ================================================================================ The Timberwolves have a clear height advantage vs. the Mavericks in the Western Conference Finals, and our NBA betting picks expect Karl-Anthony Towns to take advantage of mismatches in Game 1. ! • Betting Analyst May 22, 2024 • 17:25 ET • 4 min read !This article contains predictions for an old game! ! Photo By - USA TODAY Sports The Minnesota Timberwolves may still be riding high from their historic comeback to win Game 7 in Denver. Their fans certainly still are. Then again, Target Center was just as high for Game 3 of the last series, and that led to a Nuggets rout. The Dallas Mavericks have reason to believe in an upset tonight. But do they have reason to believe they can slow down the player currently shining brightest for Minnesota? No, that is not Anthony Edwards. Rather, our free will put faith in the longest-tenured Timberwolf as we dig into Mavs vs Timberwolves predictions for Wednesday, May 22. And don't miss Jon Metler's  for Game 1! Mavs vs Timberwolves prediction ------------------------------- **My best bet** Karl-Anthony Towns Over 19.5 points () **Best odds available in your region** **My analysis **Who on the roster is the best matchup for the ' most versatile offensive threat? And make no mistake, no matter how high ’ star reaches this postseason, remains the best offensive piece for the Timberwolves, though he's sometimes inconsistent. The last time 6-foot-7 P.J. Washington began a game as Towns’ primary defender, Towns scored 62 points in January. He will not get this assignment. Daniel Gafford, 6-foot-10, has been starting this postseason and then yielding many minutes to rookie Dereck Lively II. Gafford is many things — an energetic player, an attacking rebounder, an excellent lob finisher — but a defensive ace is not among them. Towns’ variety of post moves will bother Gafford, and Gafford cannot sell out against them because Towns will also make him work from the perimeter. Lively’s 7-foot-1 length may be a better matchup, but the rookie would be in well over his head. And, again, he has not been starting. With Minnesota starting both Towns and , playing them both notably more than 30 minutes per game last round, despite the series being rife with blowouts, Dallas needs to find a way to play two bigs more regularly. Washington as the second-biggest Maverick on the floor for many minutes will be an recipe for interior disaster. This is where the loss of Maxi Kleber (shoulder injury, possibly returning by the end of the series) looms largest. He may not seem a significant defensive piece, but Kleber would be a better matchup than Washington, and he would give Dallas a semblance of size. As is, Jason Kidd’s best option may be to play both Lively and Gafford — possibly to the detriment of Derrick Jones Jr., though that would then force Washington or Luka Doncic to hang with Edwards. Even with that lineup, Towns will be going against an overmatched defender. After Towns excelled defensively the last two series, somewhat slowing Kevin Durant and Nikola Jokic, he should now have a chance to dominate offensively. He has cracked 20 points in five of his last eight games, showing increasing lower-body strength only two months removed from knee surgery. He might crack 20 points in five of the games in this series. key_points: The Mavericks lead the series 3-1 against the Timberwolves, who are facing elimination in Game 5.
The betting line for Game 5 has the over/under set at 209.5 total points.
The Timberwolves have performed well in the first half of the series, going 3-1 against the spread (ATS) in the first half.
Mavericks center Dereck Lively II's participation is uncertain due to a concussion, impacting the team's performance metrics.
The prediction suggests the Timberwolves will win, but the Mavericks are noted for their strong second-half performance this postseason.
Key betting picks include Timberwolves -2.5 in the first half, Luka Doncic over 9.5 rebounds, and Karl-Anthony Towns over 19.5 points.

[4] Published: May 30 2024 15:02 Title: NBA Best Bets | Picks Against Spread, Prop Predictions, Odds for Mavericks vs Timberwolves Game 5 (Thursday, May 30) Content: We have one standalone matchup on-tap in the NBA tonight, with one side looking to punch its ticket to the Finals and the other hoping to avoid elimination. The own a 3-1 lead over the , as the Wolves try to defend their home floor and stay alive with both teams fighting for a chance to face the in the . The Mavs are on the spread in Thursday's contest, with the over/under listed at 209.5 total points at . So, where does the betting value lie in Game 5 of the Western Conference Finals? Read below for our five **NBA best bets** for **Mavericks vs. Timberwolves Game 5** on **Thursday, May 30** — featuring two **picks against the spread** and **predictions** for three different **props**. **NBA Best Bets: Mavericks vs Timberwolves Game 5 (Thursday, May 30)** ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Mavericks vs. Timberwolves -------------------------- By The Wolves have their backs against the wall for a second-consecutive elimination game and if they have any hope of extending this series, they’ll need to come out with energy in the first two frames — something they’ve done in three of the four games already (3-1 ATS in the first half this series). Shams Charania reported that Mavericks center Dereck Lively II could play in Game 5 but I don’t think that’s likely in a game that isn’t nearly as dire for Dallas as it is Minnesota. He looked like he suffered a concussion, and while I’m not claiming to be a doctor, I do think it makes sense not to rush Lively back despite how critical he’s been for the Mavericks. Lively's on/off numbers are fantastic. The Mavericks have a 122.7 offensive rating and 105 defensive rating when Lively is on the court these playoffs, and a 111.7 offensive and 117.6 defensive rating without him (+23.6 Net per Basketball Reference). I think Minnesota wins the game, but the Mavs have been an excellent second-half team this postseason (11-3-2 ATS), and I trust their late-game offense much more than the Wolves. Dallas owns a Net Rating of -5.5 on the road in the first half though, compared to the Wolves +3.2 at home. Finally, the line is also a bit too long for the full game, and in the Conference Finals, that’s not something I want to worry about. Since last season, favorites laying -4 or more are just 2-12 ATS and 7-7 straight up. Fading those big favorites on the moneyline gets you a 43% ROI going back to the 2021 season. I’ll bank on the Wolves creating separation by halftime and take them -2.5 in the first half. #### **Pick: Timberwolves 1H -2.5 (-110)** * * *
* * * Mavericks vs. Timberwolves -------------------------- By Luka was tremendous on the glass yet again without Dereck Lively and racked up 15 rebounds on 17 rebound chances. While this is an incredible conversion rate, Luka has a 66% conversion rate during the playoffs. The biggest thing is Lively’s absence. Given the neck injury, and how early he was ruled out of Game 4, I'm skeptical about his availability in Game 5 when the initial expectations were that he could be ready to go by the Finals. Luka has gone over this line in six of his last nine outings without Lively, but with Gafford also averaging 10.9 rebounds on 14.4 chances. I expect Luka to be the best rebounding option for Dallas, and for him to record double-digit boards in Game 5. #### **Pick: Luka Doncic Over 9.5 Rebounds (-102)** * * *
* * * Mavericks vs. Timberwolves -------------------------- By I’ve been on this every game this series and it’s been frustrating to see Towns struggle with efficiency, but the volume has been there. Towns scored 25 on an efficient 9-of-13 from the field in Game 4, but likely would have been able to reach 30 points if he could’ve kept himself out of foul trouble. Towns also led the Wolves with a +15 plus-minus, so I have less fear of him being benched for Naz Reid here as Towns actually made a tremendously positive impact on the game in multiple ways. Towns is talented enough to score 30 or 35 points here but as long as he can stay at just average efficiency he should be able to reach 20 points tonight. Trust Towns to reach this number and sprinkle his alt lines at 25+ and 30+ points as well. #### **Pick: Karl-Anthony Towns Over 19.5 Points (-120)** * * *
* * * Mavericks vs. Timberwolves -------------------------- By All four games in this series have truly been back-and-forth affairs. In fact, this bet, for there to be any other result at the end of every quarter, has hit every game this series. Both of these teams have stretches defensively where they are super locked in, and able to shut the other team down, which leads to extended runs. This has led to comebacks in both directions. Luka left a lot on the table Tuesday, and I think he will come out super-aggressive tonight. At the same time, Minnesota is at home, and has a great shot here. I think this is a back-and-forth affair, and instead of trying to figure out who will come out on top, I’d rather jump on the bet that has hit for four straight games. Betting .25u on any other result at -126 on FanDuel. #### **Pick: To Lead After Every Quarter – Neither Team (-126)** * * *
* * * Mavericks vs. Timberwolves -------------------------- By Game 5 hosts in the conference finals are on a 10-2 S/U and ATS run since 2013 as Minnesota may be a threat to make things interesting in this series. It has been an incredibly even series as the difference between the current status of Dallas being up 3-1, and the series being over with a 4-0 Minnesota sweep comes down to only a few plays. The Wolves lost Game 1 at home in a tough situation following an emphatic Game 7 win over Denver, while Game 2 was a fluke loss in a game the Wolves deserved to win. Minnesota has had a lead with less than five minutes remaining in all four games in this series and has been the better outside shooting team. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving fell short of their early series performances in Game 4, and with Doncic's multiple ailments, the longer the series goes the worse his chances of being at full strength. Minnesota has outshot Dallas but has not been able to pull away in this series including winning by only five despite a 10% edge in field goal rate in Game 4 with turnovers and free throws favoring Dallas. Minnesota missed nine free throw attempts on Tuesday while conceding 30 points off 15 turnovers. Dallas had 14 turnovers but those led to only 15 points for Minnesota and those numbers should be expected to normalize. The Wolves were the better team in the regular season and a case can be made they have been the better team in this series by a reasonable margin despite the close finishes and the late game bounces favoring Dallas. Early market support appears to be with Minnesota, as -4.5 stands as an appealing price considering Minnesota closed at -6 in Game 2 at home. #### **Pick: Timberwolves -4.5 (-112)** * * *

And in hindsight, more questions should've been asked (amongst casual observers and on the TV shows) about the Nuggets' depth. Barring injuries, I just don't think this ends in five. The Wolves are great defensively but have their offensive shortcomings. The Mavericks can guard to a higher apex than the Nuggets, and their offense isn't always fluid either. Can P.J. Washington and Derrick Jones Jr. continue to shoot 3s? Will Karl-Anthony Towns revert to his initial playoff self? Will Doncic have his way in the pick-and-roll? Will the Wolves neutralize Irving's scoring like OKC did? There are too many questions that will need games of problem solving. Give me the over. #### **Pick: Over 5.5 Games in Series (-175)** * * * Mavs 1Q ML +120 --------------- By The Wolves are a team that starts slow and dominates in fourth quarters. They also come into this game with a rest disadvantage, and this is a potential early letdown spot after the biggest win in franchise history. On the opposite side, the Mavericks have been starting strong recently, crushing the Thunder in first quarters of their last series. The change for Dallas has been a 1-to-2 minute uptick in early playing time for Kyrie. If they're extending Kyrie a bit more, take Dallas 1Q ML. * * * Kyrie Irving to Score 30+ Points -------------------------------- By Minnesota's base defense against Kyrie will likely be to let the Mavs set picks with whoever Rudy Gobert is guarding and have the center drop and hope to get over the screen. This is what they've done in the past against Kyrie and what they did against Jamal Murray at the end of the last series. Aside from Game 7, Murray couldn’t really make the Wolves pay. Kyrie, on the other hand, can. They also may start with Mike Conley on him — a matchup Kyrie could cook — since there isn’t a great Conley hiding spot. Kyrie has 30+ in his last three games against Minnesota. He's been boom-or-bust in these playoffs, scoring 30+ three times and 23 or fewer in the other nine games. At +500, this is worth a sprinkle. I'm betting .25u on Irving to have 30+ points at +500 on (I would bet it down to +425). For a bonus, the last two times Kyrie, Luka and Anthony Edwards all played in a Dallas/Minnesota game, they each had 30+. The playoffs are a different animal, but I think this series is very unpredictable, and I wouldn’t be shocked if all three did it again. I'm adding .05u on each to have 30+ at +2612 on FanDuel. #### **Pick: Kyrie Irving to Score 30+ Points** ](https://action.onelink.me/qhpb/b9f8905d) The must-have app for NBA bettors The best NBA betting scoreboard Free picks from proven pros Live win probabilities for your bets * * * Luka Doncic Over 6.5 1Q Points ------------------------------ By Doncic has reached seven first-quarter points in 10-of-12 games this postseason, and he's accomplished the feat in 4-of-5 matchups against Minnesota since the Gobert trade. The Wolves shut down paint attempts this season, but opponents were able to exploit the mid-range. Doncic possesses an excellent in-between game, and his tendency to launch from deep off-the-dribble also adds plenty of upside. Finally, he's superb at drawing contact, and Minnesota has given up a large free-throw attempt rate all season. Doncic looked relatively healthy in Game 6 against Oklahoma City, and he enters this contest with three full days of rest. Look for him to be aggressive early. #### **Pick: Luka Doncic Over 6.5 1Q Points** * * * Luka Doncic Leading Scorer +115 ------------------------------- By Jaden McDaniels is a great defender, and it showed against the smaller Jamal Murray. Luka is just so much bigger, and he uses his size with such an elite craft. I'm looking to play Luka points overs because I think he's going to be able to create a lot for himself, and the length of the Wolves may cause problems for the surrounding players. Considering the low game total and vig prices on other bets, I considered Luka Over 28.5 at -110, over 30 at +110 and leading scorer at +115. Give me the highest payment in a threshold he can still hit scoring only 27 if this game is a sub-200 total. #### **Pick: Luka Doncic Leading Scorer +115** * * * Luka Doncic Over 28.5 Points ---------------------------- By I’m targeting Doncic to have a big game. Luka’s points prop is set at 28.5, a number he's crushed this season. Overall, Luka has averaged 32.9 points per game, but he's had some difficulty in the playoffs, scoring just 27.3 a night. Much of this was due to matchups, though. The Clippers could throw a mix of Kawhi Leonard and Terance Mann at him, while Oklahoma City deployed Lu Dort. While the Timberwolves have elite wing defenders — such as McDaniels (who I expect to start of Luka) — Luka’s size should give him the edge. Also, Luka was seemingly dealing with a knee injury throughout the Oklahoma City series but got into his stride to finish the series with 31- and 29-point performances. Here, I think Minnesota has better options to defend everyone else on the Mavericks, with Ant on Kyrie and Gobert clogging up the interior. Minnesota’s defense is elite, but Luka is a tough cover due to his skill. I’ll grab Luka to exceed 28.5 points, especially with him playing on extra rest. #### **Pick: Luka Doncic Over 28.5 Points** * * *

key_points: The Mavericks and Timberwolves face off in the 2024 Western Conference Finals, marking their second postseason series ever.
Luka Doncic averaged 36.5 points, 6.0 rebounds, and 10.5 assists in two regular-season games against Minnesota this season.
Minnesota won the regular-season series 3-1, with Doncic missing two games and Kyrie Irving missing three.
The series schedule includes Game 1 on May 22 and Game 7 on June 3, if necessary.
Doncic and Edwards are the key players to watch, with Doncic averaging 24.8 points and Edwards 23.9 points in their head-to-head matchups.
Defensive matchups will be crucial, with Doncic expected to guard Mike Conley and Edwards likely taking on Kyrie Irving.
The Timberwolves have shown a strong second-half performance in the playoffs, scoring 125.8 points per 100 possessions in the second half.

### 2024 Playoffs: West Finals | Timberwolves (3) vs. Mavericks (5)

West Finals preview: What to expect in Timberwolves-Mavericks series
====================================================================

All eyes will be on Luka Doncic and Anthony Edwards, but this series may be more about defense than offensive fireworks.

!

Michael C. Wright

Updated on May 21, 2024 3:00 AM

!in 2 regular-season games against Minnesota this season, Luka Doncic averaged 36.5 points, 6.0 rebounds, and 10.5 assists.

**• **

Consider this series a rarity, given Game 1 marks just the second postseason series between these teams. The last playoff matchup between these clubs came in the opening round of the 2002 playoffs, when a 57-win Dallas squad defeated Minnesota 3-0 before falling in the next round to Sacramento.

Interestingly, two years later, Minnesota advanced to its only appearance in the conference finals.

Superstars Luka Doncic and Anthony Edwards have faced off 10 times in the regular season with each player coming away with five wins. The Timberwolves finished 3-1 against Dallas during the 2023-24 regular season, but Doncic missed two of those games while Kyrie Irving sat out three.

* * *

**Series schedule**

Here’s how to watch the Mavericks vs. Timberwolves series:

_All times Eastern Standard Time_

**Game 1:** Mavericks vs. Timberwolves, Wednesday, May 22 (8:30 p.m., TNT)  
**Game 2:** Mavericks vs. Timberwolves, Friday, May 24 (8:30 p.m., TNT)  
**Game 3:** Timberwolves vs. Mavericks, Sunday, May 26 (8:00 p.m, TNT)  
**Game 4:** Timberwolves vs. Mavericks, Tuesday, May 28 (8:30 p.m, TNT)  
**Game 5:** Mavericks vs. Timberwolves, Thursday, May 30 (8:30 p.m, TNT) \*  
**Game 6:** Timberwolves vs. Mavericks, Saturday, June 1 (8:30 p.m, TNT) \*  
**Game 7:** Mavericks vs. Timberwolves, Monday, June 3 (8:30 p.m, TNT) \*

_\* = If necessary_

* * *

**Top storyline**

Naturally, all eyes immediately focus on young superstars Doncic and Edwards. Why not? The Mavericks guard finished third in voting for Kia MVP, while Edwards received the seventh-most votes for the award. Expect both players to generate plenty of eye-popping plays in this matchup. Doncic averages 24.8 points, 7.3 rebounds, 7.7 assists and 1.4 steals in clashes with Edwards.

The Timberwolves star produces similar numbers in head-to-head battles against Doncic (23.9 ppg, 5.3 rpg, 4.7 apg, 1.1 spg), the NBA’s leading scorer this season. It’s expected Edwards will guard Doncic’s co-star Kyrie Irving (a difficult challenge), while Jaden McDaniels starts on Doncic.

* * *

**Keep your eyes on**

**The new matchups on both sides.** Minnesota won the regular-season series, 3-1. But those games were before Dallas brought in Daniel Gafford and P.J. Washington at the trade deadline. That changes how these teams will match up. Expect rookie Dereck Lively II and Daniel Gafford to take turns on Rudy Gobert, while Washington likely draws the Karl-Anthony Towns assignment. Doncic should guard Mike Conley with Derrick Jones Jr. taking Edwards.

* * *

**1 more thing to watch for each team**

**For Mavericks:** Minnesota owns a reputation for suffocating defense, but don’t sleep on what Dallas has done in that department since the end of the regular season. The Mavericks rank sixth in postseason defensive rating (110.6), just two spots behind the Timberwolves (107.6) and a major reason for the team’s overall success on that end is Doncic’s participation.

**For Timberwolves:** Dallas dominated the paint against the smaller Oklahoma City Thunder in the last round. But Minnesota’s bigs — Gobert, Towns and Kia NBA Sixth Man of the Year Naz Reid — present a more daunting challenge. The Mavs have secured at least 14 offensive rebounds in four games so far in the playoffs. Look for Minnesota to limit those precious second-chance scoring opportunities in this series.

* * *

**Key number to know**

**19.4** — Over their 11 playoff games, the Wolves have been  better in the second half (plus-18.4) than they’ve been in the first half (minus-1.0). They’ve trailed  of the 11 games at halftime, but have won four of those seven, with the highlight being their comeback  early in the third quarter of Game 7 in Denver on Sunday.

The half-to-half difference has been almost entirely about offense. The Wolves have had the playoffs’  (106.7 points scored per 100 possessions) and its  (125.8 scored per 100). Led by Jaden McDaniels () and Mike Conley (), five of their top eight guys have significant differentials in their effective field goal percentage before halftime vs. after halftime.

The Mavs have also been much better after halftime () than in the first and second quarters (minus-3.0), with that difference also being more about offense than defense. But in the four regular-season meetings, the Wolves were  (with Dallas scoring less than a point per possession) after halftime.

_— John Schuhmann_

* * *

**The pick**

**Mavericks in seven.** It feels like Minnesota’s time, but that’s the same vibe emanating from Dallas, which is playing in the conference finals for the second time in three seasons. As skilled as Irving and Doncic are, they also possess the experience on this stage that Minnesota lacks. Edwards will undoubtedly put together some electrifying performances. But can he do it for a grueling seven games in consecutive series? Dallas seems to be peaking at the right time.

**\* \* \***

web_search_results.title: Mavericks 108-105 Timberwolves (May 22, 2024) Game Recap - ESPN
key_points: Luka Doncic scored 33 points, including 15 in the fourth quarter, leading the Mavericks to a 108-105 victory over the Timberwolves in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.
The Mavericks dominated points in the paint with a 62-38 advantage, compensating for their poor 6-for-25 shooting from three-point range.
The Timberwolves' Anthony Edwards contributed 24 points, but struggled offensively, while Karl-Anthony Towns had a late surge but ultimately fell short.
The Mavericks executed a crucial 13-0 run in the fourth quarter, with Doncic scoring seven consecutive points to take a 97-89 lead.
Wolves coach Chris Finch criticized his team's performance in clutch moments, highlighting poor shot selection and turnovers.
The game showcased the star power of both teams, with Doncic and Kyrie Irving performing well for the Mavericks against a struggling Wolves offense.
Game 2 is scheduled for Friday night in Minnesota.
web_search_results.raw_text:
<web doc>
[3]

Title: Mavericks 108-105 Timberwolves (May 22, 2024) Game Recap - ESPN
Content: MINNEAPOLIS -- —  led a strong finish for the , swishing crucial shots down the stretch, drawing a couple of fouls and even playing strong defense.

The Mavericks might not be the favorites in yet another series, but they stole home-court advantage from the  with this promising start.

Doncic had 15 of his 33 points in the fourth quarter and  scored 24 of his 30 in the first half to lift the Mavericks to a 108-105 victory over the Timberwolves in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals on Wednesday night.

Dallas had a 62-38 advantage in points in the paint to offset a 6-for-25 shooting performance from deep.

“We made important ones,” said Doncic, who scored seven straight points over 63 seconds early in the fourth quarter to fuel a 13-0 run by the Mavericks for a 97-89 lead.

The Mavericks trailed 102-98 after a 3-pointer by  with 3:37 left, before an 8-0 run the Wolves didn't stop until a tip-in with 10.5 seconds to go. For the first time in six tries under coach Jason Kidd, the Mavericks won the first game of a playoff series.

 had his third straight 20-plus-point game with 24 points for the Wolves, but Edwards — who earned his first  selection prior to the game, on the second team — was stifled for 19 points in a team effort from the Mavericks.  needed a late burst to get to 16 points and finished 6 for 20 from the floor.

The star power in this series is strong, and for the first night at least the Mavericks got what they needed from their leading duo while the Wolves largely struggled to run the offense around theirs.

“Terrible offense down the stretch: bad shots, turnovers, no composure,” Wolves coach Chris Finch said. “We've got to be better in clutch moments.”

Towns came to life with a long jumper, a lob to  for a slam and a 3-pointer on a 2-minute burst to give the Wolves the lead back with 4:39 to go on the way to a 10-0 run that Doncic ended with a 3-pointer. , who had 13 points and seven rebounds, hit from deep to put the Mavericks back in front with 1:56 to go.

Towns thought he tied the game with a putback dunk on the next possession, but that was waved off for basket interference.

Minnesota hosts Game 2 on Friday night.

Edwards, who went scoreless in the third quarter, added 11 rebounds and eight assists.

“He’s an amazing player. We have to put multiple bodies on him,” Doncic said. “If he’s going 1-on-1, it’s kind of tough to stop him.”

 had 15 points and  added 11 points off the bench for the Wolves, who had two days off after dethroning defending champion Denver with a Game 7 comeback from a 20-point deficit to win the second-round series.

The transition was sharp from the Nuggets and NBA MVP Nikola Jokic’s deliberate and powerful style to the pick-and-roll-heavy Mavericks, who frequently lost their opponents off screens for wide-open dunks. They moved with a purpose that kept the Wolves from consistently setting their half-court defense around the NBA Defensive Player of the Year Gobert at the rim.

Irving’s stunning burst on the break and on the drive presented a unique challenge the Wolves and their league-leading defense didn’t face in the last round, when they held the Nuggets to an average of 85 points over their four wins.

“He got us going. Without him, we would probably be down 20 at halftime,” Doncic said. “I had to help him in the second half a little bit. So we switched roles this time.”

McDaniels, who played his usual relentless defense on the perimeter, was the catalyst on the other end of the court too with five 3-pointers in the first half, but Towns had trouble getting shots to fall and Edwards found his driving lanes constantly clogged.

“Jaden was the only one that came ready to play tonight,” Edwards said, “and I think everyone else let him down.”

The Mavericks have cranked up their defense since adding  and Washington at the trade deadline, as top-seeded Oklahoma City can attest after losing in six games in the last round. Doncic chipped in, too, breaking up a lob from  to Gobert for one of his three steals with 1:06 remaining and the Mavericks leading by two.

“No one panicked. There was just a lot of trust, no matter how bad or how good we’re playing,” Kidd said.

\------

Mavericks @ Timberwolves Game 5 Analysis & +1100 SGP
====================================================

!

Ben DiGiacomo

Host · Writer



Game 5 between the Dallas Mavericks and Minnesota Timberwolves is set for tonight in the Twin Cities, with the Wolves aiming to keep their championship hopes alive. After a rocky first three games, it almost seemed like the Wolves got some of their swagger back in Game 4. The Timberwolves sit as 4.5-point favorites tonight, but can they pull off the comeback? Regardless, tonight should be fun, so we have you covered with everything you need to know, as well as a +1100 ultimate same-game parlay.

Let’s have ourselves a night!

_Dunk on the sportsbooks tonight! SportsGrid’s free , , and ._

**8:30 p.m. ET:** **No. 5 Dallas Mavericks @ No. 3 Minnesota Timberwolves** **(Mavericks Lead 3-1)**
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

*   **Spread:** Timberwolves -4.5 | **Moneyline:** Timberwolves -194 | **Total:** 209.5
*   **Where to Watch:** TNT | **Location:** Target Center (Minneapolis, MN)

**Mavericks Last 5 ATS:** 3-2 | **Timberwolves** **Last** **5 ATS:** 2-3

**SportsGrid’s Best Bets**: Mavericks +4.5 (1-Star) | UNDER 209.5 (2-Stars)

**SportsGrid’s Top Player Props**: **** OVER 3.5 Three-Point FG Made (4.5-Stars) | **** UNDER 11.5 Rebounds (5-Stars)

**Elsewhere Around the Association**
------------------------------------

**_NBA Headliners:_  | **



**Timberwolves-Mavericks +1100 SGP**
====================================

_Dunk on the sportsbooks tonight! SportsGrid’s free , , and ._

**Legs 1 & 2: Luka Doncic 3+ Threes, 8+ Rebounds**
--------------------------------------------------

**** has **knocked down at least three shots from beyond the arc in each game this series**, averaging 10.8 attempts from deep per game. If Luka chucks up at least ten shots from deep, I’ll undoubtedly count on him being able to knock down three. His rebound production is coming off a **15-rebound performance in Game 4**, so I trust he can rack up eight tonight.

**Legs 3 & 4: PJ Washington Jr. 2+ Threes, 4+ Rebounds**
--------------------------------------------------------

**** has **made at least two threes in nine of his last ten games**, and he’s **grabbed at least four rebounds in every playoff game thus far**. What else is there to ask for?

**Leg 5: Daniel Gafford 5+ Rebounds**
-------------------------------------

 didn’t play in Game 4, allowing  to **play 31 minutes and grab eight rebounds**. Lively is questionable tonight, and even if he does play, I can still imagine Gafford playing more than his average minutes workload, ultimately giving him more than enough chances to grab at least five rebounds.

**Legs 6 & 7: Anthony Edwards 6+ Assists, 5+ Rebounds**
-------------------------------------------------------

 has **averaged 8.3 assists and 8.8 rebounds this series**, **eclipsing the six-assist and five-rebound marks in each game**. He will want to put his team on his back again, so I expect his production to stay intact in the Wolves’ biggest game on their home floor.

**Leg 8: Mike Conley 10+ Points**
---------------------------------

 has **averaged 16.0 points over his last three games**, and it’s almost felt as if the Mavs are letting Conley get his shots up relatively quickly. They aren’t too worried about him beating them. At the minimum, he should be able to navigate to double-digit points.

**Leg 9: Rudy Gobert 10+ Points**
---------------------------------

Like with **Mike Conley**, the Mavs defensively don’t pay _much_ attention to ****, as he’s had **at least ten points in three of four games this series**, with the one miss being a nine-point outing. He’s taking few shots, but he’s doing an excellent job of camping out around the rim and putting up easy looks while getting to the free-throw line a fair amount. All of that combined should be enough to get us double-digit points.

web_search_results.title: Timberwolves-Mavericks Western Conference Finals Game 1 preview: tickets, TV channel, radio, injury report, start time
key_points: The Minnesota Timberwolves will host the Dallas Mavericks in Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals on May 22, 2024.
The Timberwolves advanced to this round by defeating the Nuggets in Game 7, while the Mavericks beat the Thunder in six games.
Game 1 will start at 7:30 PM CT at the Target Center in Minneapolis, with doors opening at 6 PM.
The game will be broadcast nationally on TNT and truTV, with radio coverage available from the Timberwolves' announcers.
Injury report: Timberwolves have no injuries, while Mavericks will be missing Maxi Kleber (right shoulder) and Olivier-Maxence Prosper (left ankle).

Timberwolves-Mavericks Western Conference Finals Game 1 preview: tickets, TV channel, radio, injury report, start time ====================================================================================================================== May 22, 20248:00 AM CDT The Minnesota Timberwolves will look to protect home court against the Dallas Mavericks in Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals on Wednesday. The Wolves beat the Nuggets in Game 7 of the second round on Sunday to advance to the Western Conference Finals. Dallas beat the Oklahoma City Thunder in six games to advance. Since the Wolves had a better regular season record than the Mavs, Minnesota has the home court advantage in this third round series. Here's everything you need to know about Wolves vs. Mavs in Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals on Wednesday, including start time, how to get tickets to the game, watch it on TV and listen on the radio. ](https://www.nba.com/timberwolves/memberships-lite) #### Game 1 tickets, doors & start time * **Tickets:** * **Doors:** 6 PM * **Start Time:** 7:30 PM Doors to this 7:30 PM game will open at 6 PM. You can get tickets to Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals . All fans at Game 1 will get a white Playoff tee, presented by Sprite and a Howl Towel, presented by Target. To learn more about in-game happenings, click . #### How to watch and listen to Wolves vs. Mavs Game 1 * **Date:** Wednesday, May 22 * **Start Time:** 7:30 PM CT  * **TV channel:** TNT | truTV, Max * **Radio:** | | * **Where:** Target Center | Minneapolis, MN Taking place at Target Center in downtown Minneapolis, Game 1 of Wolves vs. Mavs will be broadcast nationally on TNT at 7:30 PM on Wednesday, May 22. Play-by-play announcer Kevin Harlan, analysts Reggie Miller and Stan Van Gundy and reporter Allie LaForce will be calling the game for TNT. You can listen to Alan Horton, the radio voice of the Timberwolves, and color analyst Jim Petersen call the game on , and the . The Timberwolves' radio broadcast will start 15 minutes before tip. On truTV and Max, there'll be an alternative viewing experience hosted by Jordan Cornette and will feature Vince Carter, Bomani Jones and Chris Haynes. #### Injury Report  _Note: Today's injury report may be updated before the start of the game._ **Wolves** * Nothing to report The Wolves don’t have any players listed on their injury report. **Mavs** * **Out:** Maxi Kleber, Olivier-Maxence Prosper Maxi Kleber (Right Shoulder; AC Separation) and Olivier-Maxence Prosper (Left Ankle Sprain) are out. #### Jerseys  * **Wolves:** * **Mavs:** Statement Edition  The Wolves will be wearing their against the Mavs. The game will be played on a matching Classic Edition court. Dallas will be playing in their dark blue Statement Edition uniforms. #### Wolves vs. Mavs series schedule and results

web_search_results.title: Dallas Mavericks vs Minnesota Timberwolves Injury Reports for January 31 | 2023-24 NBA Season
key_points: The Dallas Mavericks and Minnesota Timberwolves will face each other for the fourth time this season on January 31, 2024.
The Timberwolves lead the season series 2-1 and aim to secure the tiebreaker.
Minnesota holds a 33-14 record, leading the Western Conference, while the Mavericks are 30-15, looking to improve their standings.
Key injuries for the Mavericks include Luka Doncic (right ankle sprain), Kyrie Irving (right thumb sprain), and Dereck Lively II (broken nose), all ruled out.
Dante Exum and Derrick Jones Jr. are listed as doubtful for the Mavericks.
For the Timberwolves, Mike Conley (left hamstring soreness) is questionable, while Jaylen Clark (right Achilles tendon rupture) is out.
The game is set to tip off at 8:00 PM ET at the Target Center in Minneapolis.

web_search_results.title: Dallas Mavericks And Minnesota Timberwolves Game 1 Injury Reports
key_points: The Dallas Mavericks and Minnesota Timberwolves announced their injury reports for Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals on May 22, 2024.
Luka Doncic of the Mavericks is listed as probable but expected to play, while Mike Conley of the Timberwolves is listed as questionable.
The Mavericks ruled out Maxi Kleber and Olivier-Maxence Prosper for the game.
The Mavericks are the fifth seed with a 50-32 record, while the Timberwolves are the third seed with a 56-26 record.
Both teams won their respective playoff series to reach the Conference Finals.
Game 1 is scheduled for 7:30 PM CT at the Target Center.

Published: May 22 2024 19:37
Title: Dallas Mavericks And Minnesota Timberwolves Game 1 Injury Reports
Content: Dallas Mavericks And Minnesota Timberwolves Game 1 Injury Reports
===============

*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   

](https://www.si.com/fannation/nba/fastbreak/)

*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   

UPDATE: Dallas Mavericks And Minnesota Timberwolves Game 1 Injury Reports
=========================================================================

The Dallas Mavericks and Minnesota Timberwolves have announced their injury reports for Game 1.

####  | May 22, 2024

!

Dec 19, 2022; Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA; Dallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic (77) looks to pass while Minnesota Timberwolves guard Anthony Edwards (1) defends during the first quarter at Target Center. Mandatory Credit: Matt Krohn-USA TODAY Sports / Matt Krohn-USA TODAY Sports



* * *

**: Mike Conley is available.**

**: Luka Doncic is available.**

On Wednesday evening, the Dallas Mavericks and the Minnesota Timberwolves will face off at the Target Center for Game 1 of the Western Conference Finals.

For the game, both teams have announced their injury reports (updated as of 3:30 Eastern Time).

The Mavs have ruled out Maxi Kleber and Olivier-Maxence Prosper while All-Star forward Luka Doncic is listed as probable.

Since he is probable, Doncic should be available.

Meanwhile, the Timberwolves have listed starting point guard Mike Conley as questionable and no one else is on their injury report for Game 1.

!

NBA Injury Report / Timberwolves-Mavs Injury Reports

The Mavs are the fifth seed in the Western Confernece with a 50-32 record.

They beat the Los Angeles Clippers and the Oklahoma City Thunder in the first two rounds of the playoffs.

Last season, the Mavs missed the NBA playoffs, but they reached the Conference Finals in 2022.

As for the Timberwolves, they are the third seed in the Western Conference with a 56-26 record.

They beat the Phoenix Suns and the Denver Nuggets in the first two rounds of the playoffs.

Last season, the Timberwolves lost to the Nuggets in the first round.

> Game 1 of the WCF.  
>   
> 🆚   
> ⌚ 7:30PM CT  
> 📺   
> 📻 97.1 FM and 99.1 FM 
> 
> — Dallas Mavericks (@dallasmavs) 

Game 2 of the series will be on Friday evening (also at the Target Center).

Whoever wins the series will advance to the NBA Finals and face off against either the Boston Celtics or the Indiana Pacers.

That series is 1-0 in favor of the Celtics with Game 2 on Thursday evening in Boston.

The Celtics are in the Conference Finals for the third straight year.

* * *

Published May 22, 2024|Modified May 22, 2024

!

Ben Stinar is the NBA reporter for Fastbreak on FanNation.

Follow @BenStinar



* * *

web_search_results.title: Dallas Mavericks vs. Minnesota Timberwolves All-Time Head-to-Head Record in the NBA
key_points: The Dallas Mavericks and Minnesota Timberwolves have played a total of 144 games against each other in the NBA, including regular season and playoffs.
In the regular season, the Mavericks have won 77 games while the Timberwolves have won 59, giving the Mavericks a winning percentage of .566 compared to the Timberwolves' .434.
In the NBA playoffs, the Mavericks have a significant advantage, winning 7 out of 8 playoff games against the Timberwolves, resulting in a winning percentage of .875.
The Mavericks have won 2 playoff series against the Timberwolves, while the Timberwolves have not won any.
The historical performance data includes games played from the 1980-81 season to the 2024-25 season.

web_search_results.title: Dallas Mavericks vs. Minnesota Timberwolves Head-to-Head in the NBA Regular Season
key_points: The Dallas Mavericks and Minnesota Timberwolves have faced each other 136 times in the NBA regular season.
The Mavericks lead the all-time series with 77 wins compared to the Timberwolves' 59 losses.
Recent games include a Mavericks win on January 7, 2024 (115-108) and a Timberwolves win on January 31, 2024 (121-87).
The Timberwolves had a streak of three consecutive wins against the Mavericks from December 28, 2023, to January 31, 2024.
The Mavericks have historically dominated the matchup, winning 7 of the last 10 games played against the Timberwolves.

web_search_results.title: Minnesota Timberwolves Historical Statistics and All-Time Top Leaders
key_points: The Minnesota Timberwolves have been active in the NBA for 36 seasons, starting from 1989-90 to 2024-25.
The team's overall win-loss record is 1149 wins and 1648 losses, resulting in a winning percentage of .411.
The Timberwolves have made 12 playoff appearances but have not won any championships.
The franchise's best season was 2003-04, finishing with a record of 58 wins and 24 losses, and they reached the playoffs that year.
The Timberwolves have had fluctuating performance, with several seasons finishing below .300 win percentage.

web_search_results.title: 2024 NBA Western Conference Finals - Mavericks vs. Timberwolves
key_points: The Dallas Mavericks faced the Minnesota Timberwolves in the 2024 NBA Western Conference Finals.
The Mavericks won the series 4-1, securing their place in the NBA Finals.
Key players for the Mavericks included Luka Dončić, who scored 33 points in Game 1 and 32 points in Game 2.
The Timberwolves won Game 4 with Anthony Edwards scoring 29 points, but were ultimately eliminated in Game 5.
In Game 5, the Mavericks defeated the Timberwolves 124-103, with Luka Dončić contributing 36 points.

web_search_results.title: Minnesota Timberwolves - Wikipedia
key_points: The Minnesota Timberwolves were founded in 1989 and are part of the NBA's Western Conference Northwest Division.
The team has never won an NBA Championship or Conference title, with only one Division title in their history.
The franchise experienced early struggles but made the playoffs for the first time in 1997, led by stars Kevin Garnett and Stephon Marbury.
The Timberwolves reached the Western Conference Finals in the 2003-04 season but lost to the Los Angeles Lakers.
After trading Garnett in 2007, the team entered a rebuilding phase and struggled to return to the playoffs until 2018.
The Timberwolves have seen a resurgence in recent years, highlighted by the emergence of players like Karl-Anthony Towns and Anthony Edwards.
In the 2023-24 season, the Timberwolves reached the Conference Finals for the first time since 2004, ultimately losing to the Dallas Mavericks.

The **Minnesota Timberwolves** (often referred to as the **Wolves**) are an American professional  team based in . The Timberwolves compete in the  (NBA) as a member of the  "Northwest Division (NBA)") of the  "Western Conference (NBA)"). The team was founded in 1989. Its majority owner is , who also owns the 's . Currently, Taylor is in a legal battle over ownership of the team with , , and . The Timberwolves play their home games at , their home since 1990.

Like most , the Timberwolves struggled in their early years, but after the acquisition of  in the , the team qualified for the  in eight consecutive seasons from  to . Despite losing in the first round in their first seven attempts, the Timberwolves won their first division championship in  and advanced to the  that same season. Garnett was also named the  for that season. The team then went into rebuilding mode for more than a decade after missing the postseason in 2005, and trading Garnett to the  in 2007. Garnett returned to the Timberwolves in a February 2015 trade and finished his career there, retiring in the 2016 off-season. The Timberwolves ended a 14-year playoff drought when they returned to the postseason in .

### 1989–1995: Team creation and early years

\\]

NBA basketball returned to the  in 1989 for the first time since the  (1947–1960) departed to  in . The NBA had granted one of its four new expansion teams on April 22, 1987 (the others being the , , and the ) to original owners Harvey Ratner and Marv Wolfenson to begin play beginning in the . There were two previous  (ABA) franchises that played in between the Lakers' departure and the Timberwolves arrival: the  (1967–68), and the  (1968–69). The Timberwolves have worn throwback uniforms for each of the previous franchises.

The franchise conducted a "name the team" contest and eventually selected two finalists, "Timberwolves" and "Polars", in December 1986. The team then asked the 842 city councils in Minnesota to select the winner and "Timberwolves" prevailed by nearly 2–1. The team was officially named the "Minnesota Timberwolves" on January 23, 1987. Minnesota is home to the largest population of  in the contiguous 48 states.

The Timberwolves debuted on November 3, 1989, losing to the  on the road 106–94. Five days later, they made their home debut at the , losing to the  96–84. Two nights later on November 10, the Wolves got their first win, beating the  at home 125–118. The Timberwolves, led by  with 23.2 ppg, went on to a 22–60 record, finishing in sixth place in the Midwest Division. Playing in the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, the expansion Timberwolves set an NBA record by drawing over 1 million fans to their home games. This included a crowd of 49,551 on April 17, 1990, which saw the Timberwolves lose to the  99–88 in the final home game of the season.

The next , the team moved into their permanent home, the , and improved somewhat, finishing 29–53. However, they fired their head coach, . They fared far worse in the  under Musselman's successor, ex- coach  "Jimmy Rodgers (basketball)"), finishing with an NBA-worst 15–67 record. Looking to turn the corner, the Wolves hired former  general manager  to the same position, but even with notable first-round selections such as  and , the Timberwolves were unable to duplicate McCloskey's "Detroit Bad Boys" success in the Twin Cities, finishing 19–63 and 20–62 the next two seasons. One of the few highlights from that era was when the Target Center served as host of the 1994  where Rider won the  with his between-the-leg "East Bay Funk Dunk".

As winning basketball continued to elude the Wolves, Ratner and Wolfenson  in 1994 before NBA owners rejected the proposed move. Eventually,  bought the team and named  "Kevin McHale (basketball)") general manager. The Wolves finished 21–61 in 1994–95, and the future looked bleak.

### 1995–2007: The Kevin Garnett era

\\]

](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kevin_Garnett_with_the_Minnesota_Timberwolves_dunking,_2007.jpg)

 played for the Timberwolves from 1995 to 2007 before returning in 2015.

In the , the Timberwolves selected high school standout  in the first round (5th overall), and  was named head coach.  was traded along with  to the  for  "Andrew Lang (basketball)") and . Also, first-round pick  was traded the previous season for ' forward . These trades paved the way for rookie Kevin Garnett to become the go-to player inside. Garnett went on to average 10.4 ppg in his rookie season as the Wolves finished in 5th place in the Midwest Division, with a 26–56 record.

In 1996, the Wolves added another star player in the draft, trading  to the  for the rights to , the 4th overall pick. The addition of Marbury had a positive effect on the entire team, as Garnett and Gugliotta became the first Wolves to be selected to the All-Star team. Gugliotta and Garnett led the Timberwolves in scoring as the team made the playoffs for the first time in franchise history with a record of 40–42. However,  the Timberwolves made a quick exit as they were swept by the  in three straight games. The T-Wolves also decided to change their image by changing their team logo and color scheme, adding black to the team colors and replacing the original logo with one featuring a snarling wolf looming over a field of trees. It was also during this season that Minnesota began to play on a .

In 1997, Garnett and Marbury established themselves as two of the brightest rising stars in the . Garnett averaged 18.5 ppg and 9.6 rebounds per game, while Marbury averaged 17.7 ppg and dished out 8.6 assists per game. Despite losing leading scorer Tom Gugliotta for half the season, the Timberwolves went on to post their first winning season at 45–37, making the playoffs for the second straight season. After dropping Game 1 of the playoffs on the road to the , the Timberwolves won their first postseason game in Game 2, winning in  98–93. As the series shifted to Minnesota, the Timberwolves had an opportunity to pull off the upset as they won Game 3 by a score of 98–90. However, the Wolves dropped Game 4 at home as the Sonics went on to win the series in five games.

In 1998, a year after signing Kevin Garnett to a six-year, $126 million contract, the Timberwolves were then used as the poster child of irresponsible spending as the NBA endured a four-month lockout that wiped out much of the season. With an already cap-heavy payroll, the Wolves let Tom Gugliotta walk, partially because the team wanted to save money in order to sign Stephon Marbury to a long-term contract, and in part because Gugliotta did not want to play with the young player. This move proved unsuccessful, however, as Stephon Marbury wanted to be the biggest star on a team and subsequently forced an in-season trade by refusing a contract extension. In the three-team mid-season deal that sent Marbury to the , the Wolves got  in return and a first-round draft pick in the 1999 draft (which turned out to be the sixth pick). The Wolves made the playoffs for the third straight season by finishing in fourth place with a 25–25 record. In the playoffs, the Timberwolves were beaten by the eventual champion  in four games.

In 1999, the Timberwolves drafted  with the sixth pick in the draft. He had a solid season, finishing third on the team in scoring with 11.6 points per game. Led by Kevin Garnett, who averaged 22.9 points per game and 11.8 rebounds per game, the Timberwolves had their first 50-win season and finished in 3rd place with a record of 50–32. However, in the playoffs the Wolves again fell in the first round, losing to the  in four games. The Wolves opened the 1999–2000 regular season with two home games against the  at the  on November 6 and 7.

In the summer of 2000, guard  was killed in a car accident by a drunk driver. Sealy's number has since been retired: the number 2 jersey memorialized with Sealy's name on a banner hanging from the rafters of Target Center. It remains the only number retired by the team.

Also in that season, a free agent deal signed by  "Joe Smith (basketball)") was voided by the NBA, who ruled that the Timberwolves violated proper procedure in signing the contract. The league stripped the Timberwolves of five draft picks (first round 2001–2005), but it was eventually reduced to three first-round picks (2001, 2002, and 2004). The league also fined the Timberwolves $3.5 million and suspended general manager Kevin McHale for one year. Smith eventually signed with the  before re-signing with the Timberwolves in 2001. Despite those setbacks, the Timberwolves made the playoffs for the fifth straight season with a 47–35 record. In the playoffs, the Timberwolves were eliminated in the first round again by the  in four games in the spring of 2001.

A number of newcomers arrived prior to the start of the next season, including ,  and  "Maurice Evans (basketball)") and the return of  "Joe Smith (basketball)"). The Timberwolves started the season by winning their first six games and went on to achieve a franchise-best start of 30–10. The Timberwolves had a franchise-record 53-point win over  in November. They finished with a 50–32 record: their second-ever 50-win season that was highlighted by another All-Star appearance by Garnett and a breakout season by , who earned his first All-Star appearance. Once again, Minnesota lost in the first round of the playoffs, where they were swept by the  in three straight games.

The  seemed to look up for the Timberwolves. Garnett had a great season where he finished second in  voting with 23.0 points per game and 13.4 rebounds per game and the Timberwolves finished in third place with a 51–31 record. As a result, they were awarded home-court advantage for the first time when facing the three-time defending champion . After losing at home in Game 1, the Timberwolves had a chance to take a 3–1 series lead heading into the 4th quarter of Game 4 in Los Angeles, but the Lakers came back to win the game and eventually won the series in six games. In the end, the Timberwolves were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs for the seventh straight year.

#### 2003–04 season: Western Conference finals appearance

\\]

In 2003,  was promoted to vice-president of player personnel. He and general manager  "Kevin McHale (basketball)") made a series of strong off-season moves in an attempt to get the team over the hump and beyond the first round of the playoffs. They made two important trades, sending away forward  "Joe Smith (basketball)") and guard  in a multi-player deal for ,  and embattled guard . They also signed sharp-shooter , and former first overall pick  as free agents, with both becoming key contributors during the season. The Timberwolves rounded out their bench by signing veteran role players , , and  "Mark Madsen (basketball)").

Despite injuries to a revitalized Olowokandi (who missed half the season) and 6th man  (who only played in 28 games), the revamped Timberwolves became the team to beat during the , finishing the season as the top seed in the Western Conference with a record of 58–24. Garnett had his best season to date, and both Sprewell and Cassell had career years as well. Garnett and Cassell both made , and after the season, Garnett was named , and earned his first  averaging 24.2 points, 13.9 rebounds and 5.0 assists per game.

During the , the Wolves won their first-ever playoff series against the , before beating the  in a hard-fought seven-game series to advance to the franchise's first Western Conference finals.  leapt upon the scorer's table upon the winning Game 7 in the Sacramento series, which became one of the more iconic moments in Minnesota sports history. The Timberwolves' run ended in the Western Conference finals as the team lost to the .  injured his groin during Game 7 against the Kings, doing his infamous _big balls_ dance after knocking down the series-clinching bucket, and as a result, played only sparingly during the Lakers series. Many around the NBA, including both  and  believe that had he been healthy, the Wolves would have advanced to the finals.

#### Departure of Flip Saunders

\\]

](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:012308-TC-Twolves001.jpg)

The Timberwolves conduct pre-game warm-ups at their home Arena, the 

Going into the , the Wolves roster remained virtually the same from the previous season; however, Babcock left to become the general manager of the , and the team was also plagued with contract disputes and the complaining of key players , , and  during the off-season. After a disappointing start to the season, head coach  was replaced by general manager and long-time friend  "Kevin McHale (basketball)"), who took over as coach for the rest of the season. Despite a strong finish, the Timberwolves missed the playoffs for the first time in eight years, by one game, to the , ending the season with a record of 44–38.

During the 2005 off-season, McHale and the Wolves started their search for a head coach. McHale interviewed  assistant coach ,  assistant , former coach  and Wolves assistants ,  and , among others.

On June 17, 2005, the Timberwolves hired Casey as the new head coach. It was Casey's first head coaching job, making him the Wolves' seventh head coach in their 16-year history.

The Minnesota Timberwolves' wordmark logo used from 2008 to 2017.

In their inaugural season in 1989, the Timberwolves (or "Wolves" as it said on their jerseys) debuted blue road uniforms with green lettering and numbers with white. Their home uniforms featured blue lettering and numbers with green outlining. The creation of both uniforms was led by head designer, Brian Mulligan. There was going to be a green alternate jersey with blue lettering to go with the uniforms, but the idea was dropped. It would've followed a similar move the  took when they switched back to blue in the early 1990s, opting the Wolves a chance to use green for a jersey color instead. The Timberwolves would resurrect the blue uniforms from this era during the 2009–10 season, as part of the franchise's 20th anniversary.

After drafting , the Timberwolves design team, under guidance from Brian Mulligan, changed their uniforms in 1996. This time, the team added black and gray to the mix, and changing to a darker shade of blue. The front of the jerseys then said the team's full name "Timberwolves" in a different font. For the 1997–98 season, a black alternate uniform was introduced. Those uniforms were used until the 2007–08 season. The Timberwolves unveiled a new alternate logo on June 25, 2008.

The uniforms changed again in the 2008 off-season, this time with the road jerseys reading "Minnesota" and the home jerseys reading "Wolves", similar to that of the team's early years. Both uniforms had green, black, gray and blue on the pits and sides of the shorts. The Timberwolves unveiled modified uniforms on August 16, 2010. The new uniforms eliminated the green from the collar, jersey and shorts, and the team also adjusted its number font again. On November 23, 2010, the Timberwolves unveiled a black alternate uniform. On November 27, 2013, the team changed their black road alternate jersey to a short sleeved jersey. The change came about due to the NBA's introduction of sleeved jerseys.

On April 11, 2017, the team unveiled a new logo to coincide with the massive roster turnaround of the past few years. The Timberwolves revealed four new uniforms for the 2017–18 season as a part of a \-sponsored, league-wide initiative to redesign team uniforms. All four uniforms used "Wolves" for the team name and included the  and  logos. The Association Edition uniform, revealed on August 10, 2017, consisted of a white uniform with navy and blue stripes and lettering. The Icon Edition uniform, which was revealed alongside its Association counterpart, has a navy body with white stripes and lettering. On September 15, the Timberwolves revealed their Statement Edition uniform which is primarily neon green with navy stripes, navy lettering for the team and player names, and white text with a navy stroke for the jersey numbers. The City Edition uniform, which is primarily gray with white lettering, was the last to be revealed on December 27.

On August 30, 2018, the Timberwolves unveiled their first "Classic" edition uniforms based on the black alternates used from 1997 to 2008. They also unveiled a dark purple "City" uniform inspired by  "Prince (musician)")'s 1984 album _ "Purple Rain (album)")_, as well as a white "Earned" version that was exclusive only to the 16 teams that made the 2018 playoffs.

The Timberwolves' 2019–20 "City" uniform, which was unveiled on November 20, 2019, featured a sky blue base with white letters and trim that paid homage to the waters of the  and the  metropolitan area (the "Twin Cities").

For the 2020–21 season, the Timberwolves' "City" uniform paid homage to the , featuring a midnight black base and aurora green trim. A green star is affixed below the neckline and above the abbreviation "MINN" in gray.

As part of the NBA's 75th anniversary, the Timberwolves' "City" uniform in the 2021–22 season mixed various elements from the franchise's previous uniforms. The royal blue base recalled the original 1989–1996 uniforms. The tree accents and lettering visually honored the 1996–2008 uniforms. The dark blue accents were inspired by the 2017–18 "City" uniforms. The original 1989–1996 logo was placed on the right leg, while the current logo was affixed on the left leg.

Beginning with the 2022–23 season, the Timberwolves unveiled a new "Statement" uniform, relegating neon green to trim color and featured a dark gray base. The full name "Timberwolves" was featured in front along with green-trimmed gray numbers. Also during the season, a new "City" uniform was unveiled, featuring a white base, black letters and stripes, and rainbow palette to represent Minnesota's colorful community.

The "City" uniform in the 2023–24 season featured a mostly blue base with white lake water gradients; the design represented the fun summertime activities of Minnesota's citizens, from camping to fishing and swimming. A special alternate court for the  was also unveiled to go with this uniform, featuring a light blue base with a lakewater blue strip in the middle. Also for the season, the Timberwolves brought back the original 1989–1996 white uniform for its "Classic" edition, this to celebrate the franchise's 35th season. This was paired with a modernized version of the original court used at the Target Center.

](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Crunch_the_Wolf_at_Target_Center.jpg)

Crunch the Wolf

**Crunch the Wolf** is the official mascot of the Minnesota Timberwolves, According to the team's official website, "Crunch was born in the northernmost part of Minnesota’s wilderness areas. Deep in the forest, he grew with a love for something never before seen by others in his pack. Crunch's love for the game of basketball puzzled his mother and father, for he seemed to pick up the game on his own. With a makeshift basket built of pine-cones and birch bark, Crunch began to refine his game when he was still just a young pup. He learned the rules and techniques that make the game of basketball so great. He studied players and coaches alike, and soon would find himself on a journey like no other. Years later, when Minnesota’s expansion team, the Timberwolves, came to town, Crunch said goodbye to all he had known growing up in the woods, and migrated south to the Twin Cities where the team was to be based. No one is quite sure where Crunch lives, but legend has it he has a den somewhere deep inside the Target Center. He is lured out on game-days by the deafening howl made by Wolves fans. This howl creates an atmosphere in the Target Center that reminds Crunch of his days back in the forest, and yet keeps him here in Minneapolis, with the pursuit of helping the team to a victory."

### Retained draft rights

\\]

The Timberwolves hold the draft rights to the following unsigned draft picks who have been playing outside the NBA. A drafted player, either an international draftee or a college draftee who is not signed by the team that drafted him, is allowed to sign with any non-NBA teams. In this case, the team retains the player's draft rights in the NBA until one year after the player's contract with the non-NBA team ends. This list includes draft rights that were acquired from trades with other teams.

As of 2023, the Minnesota Timberwolves air all of their games on the  app, with select games airing on  100.3 FM within the Twin Cities. WCCO had been the team's radio home from 2011 until the end of the 2022–23 season. Before that,  had been the Timberwolves' Twin Cities flagship station since the team's inception, except for a brief two-year hiatus to  BOB 106.1 FM for the  and  seasons. Alan Horton has been the team's radio play-by-play announcer since the 2007–08 season.

The Timberwolves' games are broadcast primarily on . But if the  and  occupy both  and Bally Sports North Extra, the game will be aired on  as Bally Sports North Extra on  Twin Cities, and the  app for viewers outside of WUCW's coverage area. The broadcasters are Michael Grady and .

web_search_results.title: National Weather Service
key_points: A strong Pacific system will affect the Intermountain West early this week with strong winds and higher elevation snow.
Record warmth is expected to spread across most of the central and eastern United States due to strong southerly winds.
There is an increased risk of rapid wildfire spread today, followed by a growing chance for severe thunderstorms in the central U.S.

!

Record Warmth Spreads Eastward; Severe Weather Potential Increases Midweek
==========================================================================

A strong Pacific system will track across the Intermountain West early this week. Strong winds and higher elevation snow will affect the Western States. Further east, strong southerly winds will usher in record warmth for most of the central and eastern United States. The threat for rapid spread of wildfires today then increasing chance for severe thunderstorms for the center of the nation.

web_search_results.title: Bay Area Weather Forecast
key_points: Current weather feels like 65°F with 57% humidity and 0% chance of precipitation.
Temperatures are expected to range from a high of 66°F to a low of 48°F today.
The chance of precipitation remains low throughout the day, peaking at 4% in the afternoon.
Upcoming days forecast mostly sunny weather with temperatures reaching up to 74°F by Wednesday.
Saturday is expected to have the highest chance of rain at 41%, with cloudy conditions and occasional showers.

web_search_results.title: NBA Weather Forecast - NBAstuffer
key_points: The article visualizes NBA teams' efficiency differentials by division.
Metrics include performance over the last 5 games (L 5) and season averages (Avg).
Different weather conditions are associated with each team's recent performance.
For example, Minnesota Timberwolves show a recent performance of L 5: -6.3 and Avg: -9.1 under 'thunder' conditions.
Dallas Mavericks have L 5: +2.1 and Avg: +4.6, categorized under 'cloudy' conditions.
